prompts.answer: Small Outline DUal In-Line Memory Module.
Hard Disk Drive.
Solid State Disk
Serial - ATA.
Local Area Network.
Personal Area Network.
Metropolitan Area Network.
Storage Area Network.
Near Field Communication
Mobile Device Management. Centralised management software for mobile devices running on a corporate network.
RAID 0 stores file blocks on stripes between two or more physical devices.
RAID 1 creates mirrored file blocks on two or more physical devices. Is faster and has a high level of redundancy but halves the amount of storage space available.
Uses striping with parity. Uses parity bits to enable reconstruction of file blocks in event of drive failure. More efficient use of space than striping in RAID 1.
Creates a stripe of mirrors. Requires at least 4 drives.

prompts.prompt: What is the difference between TCP and UDP?
prompts.answer: TCP (Transmission Control Protocol) is a connection oriented protocol that ensures delivery of packets. UDP (User Datagram Protocol) is not connection oriented and simply sends packets with no guarantee that they have arrived.
Physical layer. How network hardware communicates: electrical, optical, radio signals.
Data-link layer. The node to node transfer of frames between two devices. Contains the MAC (Media Access Control) and LLC (Logical Link Control) sub-layers.
Network layer. Transfer of packets between IP addresses. Handles routing between networks.
Transport layer. Manages the delivery and error checking of packets at the source and destination hosts.
Session layer. Controls the conversations between different computers. Where a 'connection' is defined on the OSI model.
Presentation layer. Formats the data in way that the receiving application expects it to be.
Application layer. The software application that is using the network to transfer information. This layer is where the user interacts with the data.

prompts.prompt: How does the DHCP process work?
prompts.answer: It follows DORA (Disover, Offer, Request, Acknowledgement). Client searches for DHCP servers. DHCP server sends an offer to the client. Client requests the offer. Server acknowledges the request.
Virtual Local Area Network. A logical network that operates on the same physical device as other logical networks.
Virtual Private Network. A direct connection between two remote devices over a public network. The data transferred is encrypted.
nslookup queries a DNS server and gives the mapping between domain name and ip address. Can also provide records and other information using flags.
File Transfer Protocol. Uses TCP ports 20 (data) and 21 (control). Transfers data between systems and can authenticate with a username and password.
Secure Shell. Uses TCP port 22. A shell that can communicate with remote systems that uses encryption to protect data transferred.
Telecommunication Network. Uses TCP port 23. Allows remote login to a device. Communication is in plain text and is not secure.
Simple Mail Transfer Protocol. Uses TCP port 25. Protocol used to allow mail servers to transfer emails between each other or devices to a mail server.
Domain Name System. Uses UDP port 53. Protocol that converts domain names to a corresponding IP address.

Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol. Uses UDP ports 67 and 68. Automated configuration of IP, subnet, dns for a host on a network. Can be dynamically allocated from a pool or have IP addresses reserved for a given MAC address.
Media Access Controll Address. A unique identifier tied to a network interface.
HyperText Transfer Protocol/Secure. Uses TCP port 80 (secure is 443).How web browsers transfer data such as HTML files.
Post Office Protocol (TCP 110)/ Internet Message Access Protocol(TCP 143). Protocol to receive emails from a mail server.
Server Message Block. Uses NetBIOS over TCP/IP (UDP 137, TCP 139) or direct over TCP 445. File and device sharing protocol used by Microsoft Windows.
Simple Network Management Protocol. Uses UDP 161 and 162. Protocol used to gather statistics from network devices.
Lightweight Directory Access Protocol. Uses TCP port 389. Used to store and retrieve information in a network directory.
Remote Desktop Protocol. Uses TCP port 3389. Protocol used for remote access to a computers desktop.
Spanning Tree Protocol. A method of finding a route between a source and destination on a network. Used when multiple links are available which allows for redundant network designs.
Data Over Cable Service Interface Specification. Data provided over a cable network using a cable modem.

prompts.prompt: What is the base wireless network standard?
prompts.answer: 802.11. Is updated over time and various versions of this standard have been released (a, b, g, n, ac, ax).
Original wireless standard that operates in the 5GHz range. Speeds of up to 54 Mb/s. Has a smaller range than 802.11b but less interference.

Original wireless standard that operates in the 2.4GHz range. Speeds of up to 11Mb/s. Has a higher range than 802.11a but has more interference from other household devices that also operate in the 2.4GHz range.
802.11.g is an upgrade to 802.11b. It operates in the 2.4GHz range so has the same conflict problems as 802.11b. Has speeds up to 54Mb/s but is also backwards compatible with 802.11b.

802.11n (also known as WiFi 4) is the upgrade to the a,b, and g protocols. Can work in both 5GHz and 2.4GHz ranges. Can reach speeds of up to 600Mb/s by utilising MIMO technology (Multiple input multiple output).
802.11ac (also known as WiFi 5) is the upgraded version of 802.11n. It operates in the 5GHz which allows for greater channel bandwidth. Uses 8 MU-MIMO streams to reach nearly 7Gb/s speeds.

The 6th iteration of WiFi protocols is the upgrade to 802.11ac. Can operate at 5GHz or 2.4GHz. Uses Bi-directional MU-MIMO streams with 1201 Mb/s speeds on each channel. Utilises OFDMA which is a technology similar to cellular communication.
GSM and CDMA.

Global System for Mobile Communications. A mobile networking standard that uses multiplexing to separate calls - Everyone gets a little slice of time. Originally used mainly in Europe or by AT&T in US.
Code Division Multiple Access. A mobile networking standard where each communication session has its own code to distinguish it.
3G gives improved speed over 2G. This extra speed allows for new functionality such as GPS, mobile streaming, etc.

prompts.prompt: What are the benefits of 4G technology?
prompts.answer: 4G is also known as LTE or Long Term Evolution. Combines the GSM and CDMA standards. Has a standard download speed of 150Mb/s or with LTE-Advanced 300Mb/s.
Significant performance improvements over 4G that works by using higher frequencies. Low end of speed goes from 100-900Mb/s to future speeds of up to 10Gb/s.
Global Positioning System. Technology that utilises satellites in space to find the precise location of a device.
